fr.sii.ogham.core.builder

Class MessagingBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.MessagingBuilder
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Builder<MessagingService>

    public class MessagingBuilder
extends Object
implements Builder<MessagingService>
    Ogham provides many useful behaviors to focus on the message content and not the need of understanding and implementing complex protocols. Sending emails seems to be easy but the RFCs (RFC5321, RFC821, ...) are long and complex. If you don't know those RFCs, some email clients won't be able to read your emails. This is the same with the SMPP protocol used for sending SMS. The builder is a helper to instantiate and configure a MessagingService. The MessagingService is used to send:
    • Email messages
    • Sms messages
    Content of the messages can be provided by templates. Templates are parsed by template engines. Several template engines are supported:
    • Thymeleaf
    • Freemaker
    Ogham allows to send Email and Sms using several implementations:
    • JavaMail (STMP) or SendGrid (HTTP) for sending Email
    • Cloudhopper (SMPP) or OVH (HTTP) for sending Sms
    The aim is to provide an abstraction to construct a portable message ( Email or Sms) and to be able to change infrastructure (SMTP server to online HTTP service for example) without changing your code.

    Here is an example of standard configuration that provides a default behavior that fits 95% of usages: 

     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standard()
   .build();
 // send the email
 service.send(new Email()
   .body().template("email/sample", new SampleBean("foo", 42))
   .to("Foo Bar <foo.bar@sii.fr>"))
   .attach().file("file:/data/reports/report1.pdf");
    This sample shows that:
    • System properties are used to configure "mail.host" and "mail.port"
    • As properties "mail.host" and "mail.port" are defined and "ogham-email-javamail" is used, the email is sent using JavaMail implementation
    • An email is sent to "foo.bar@sii.fr"
    • The email provides a main content (HTML) and a fallback content (text)
      • The HTML content comes from a template located in the classpath (email/sample.html) and variables that are present in the template are replaced by values provided by a simple bean object (no conversion is needed). As "ogham-template-thymeleaf" is used and the template is a Thymeleaf template (Thymeleaf directive on <html> tag), this template is parsed by Thymeleaf
      • The text content comes from a template located in the classpath (email/sample.txt.ftl) and variables that are present in the template are replaced by values provided by a simple bean object (no conversion is needed). As "ogham-template-freemarker" is used and the template is a Freemarker template (".ftl" extension), this template is parsed by Freemarker
    • The HTML template has CSS styles that are inlined (CSS are forbidden by many email clients but inlined styles attributes are allowed)
    • The HTML template references images (using <img>) that are automatically attached to the sent email (mimetype of each image has been detected and indicated to the sent message)
    • A file located on the filesystem is attached to the email, its mimetype has been automatically detected and indicated to the sent message
    • The subject is provided by the <title> tag of the HTML
    • The sender email address is provided by the system property "ogham.email.from.default-value"

    Here is an example of minimal configuration that provides same default behavior as previous exemple but no sender implementation is registered. You then have to enable implementation(s) and configure them: 

     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.minimal()
   .email()
     .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)
       .host().properties("${mail.host}").and()
       .port().properties("${mail.port}").and()
       .charset().properties("${ogham.email.javamail.body.charset}").defaultValue("UTF-8").and()
       .mimetype()
         .tika()
           .failIfOctetStream(false)
           .and()
         .and()
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email
 service.send(new Email()
   .body().template("email/sample", new SampleBean("foo", 42))
   .to("Foo Bar <foo.bar@sii.fr>"))
   .attach().file("file:/data/reports/report1.pdf");
    This sample has the same effect as the previous one (for this case, some options of JavaMail implementation are not enabled). Moreover, if you want to send a Sms, you will also need to register and configure at least one SMS sender implementation. To benefit of all advantages but keeping control on which implementations are use, you can register implementation configurers: 
     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.minimal()
   .register(new DefaultJavaMailConfigurer(), 50000)     // enable sending Email through SMTP
   .register(new DefaultSendGridConfigurer(), 30000)     // enable sending Email through HTTP (using an online service)
   .register(new DefaultCloudHopperConfigurer(), 40000)  // enable sending SMS through SMPP
   .register(new DefaultOvhSmsConfigurer(), 20000)     // enable sending SMS through HTTP (using an online service)
   .build();
 // send the email
 service.send(new Email()
   .body().template("email/sample", new SampleBean("foo", 42))
   .to("Foo Bar <foo.bar@sii.fr>"))
   .attach().file("file:/data/reports/report1.pdf");
    This sample has the same effect as using standard(). You can create your own configurer for any sender implementation and register it too. You can then mutualize and externalize reusable configuration.

    The predefined behaviors are brought by static factory methods standard() and minimal(). If you don't want to use predefined behaviors, you can use directly new MessagingBuilder() or empty() static factory. Those factory methods rely on MessagingConfigurers to provide predefined behaviors.

    The default behaviors can be used and customized: 

     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standard()
   .environment()
     .properties()
       .set("mail.host", "localhost")
       .set("mail.port", "25")
       .and()
     .and()
   .mimetype()
     .defaultMimetype("application/octet-stream")
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email
 service.send(new Email()
   .body().template("email/sample", new SampleBean("foo", 42))
   .to("Foo Bar <foo.bar@sii.fr>"))
   .attach().file("file:/data/reports/report1.pdf");
    The previous sample shows how to change default behaviors to fit your needs:
    • It set the SMTP host and port in the code not by using system properties
    • It overrides default mimetype to provide a mimetype that fit your needs when mimetype detection is not enough accurate

    The MessagingService may open some resources (files, sockets, ...). The built MessagingService is wrapped by CleanableMessagingService. This way the instantiated service can clean opened resources either manually (if developer explicitly calls CleanableMessagingService.clean()) or automatically (see CleanableMessagingService for more information).

    Author:
    Aurélien Baudet

    • Constructor Detail

      • MessagingBuilder

        public MessagingBuilder(boolean autoconfigure)
        Initializes the builder with minimal requirements:
        • an empty EnvironmentBuilder
        • an empty MimetypeDetectionBuilder
        • an empty ResourceResolutionBuilder

        If autoconfigure parameter is true, it applies all registered configurers on this builder instance. When using standard() and minimal() factory methods, autoconfigure parameter is set to true.

        Parameters:
        autoconfigure - Trigger configuration automatically if true (for all phases). If false, you have to call configure(ConfigurationPhase) manually.

    • Method Detail

      • register

        public MessagingBuilder register(MessagingConfigurer configurer,
                                 int priority)
        Registers a configurer with a priority. Configuration order may be important. The priority is used to apply configurers in order. The configurer with highest priority (applied first) has the greatest value. The configurer is applied on a this builder instance to configure it (when configure(ConfigurationPhase) is called).

        When using standard() and minimal() factory methods, the list of configurers are automatically loaded from the classpath and registered. The priority is indicated through the ConfigurerFor annotation.

        The registered configurer will be executed at ConfigurationPhase.BEFORE_BUILD phase.

        Parameters:
        configurer - the configurer to register
        priority - the configurer priority
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • register

        public MessagingBuilder register(MessagingConfigurer configurer,
                                 int priority,
                                 ConfigurationPhase phase)
        Registers a configurer with a priority. Configuration order may be important. The priority is used to apply configurers in order. The configurer with highest priority (applied first) has the greatest value. The configurer is applied on a this builder instance to configure it (when configure(ConfigurationPhase) is called).

        When using standard() and minimal() factory methods, the list of configurers are automatically loaded from the classpath and registered. The priority is indicated through the ConfigurerFor annotation.

        Parameters:
        configurer - the configurer to register
        priority - the configurer priority
        phase - register the configurer to be executed at the defined the configuration phase
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • configure

        public void configure(ConfigurationPhase phase)
        Apply all registered configurers on this builder instance for the ConfigurationPhase.

        When using standard() and minimal() factory methods, this method is automatically called.

        Parameters:
        phase - the configuration phase

      • environment

        public EnvironmentBuilder<MessagingBuilder> environment()
        Configures environment for the builder (and sub-builders if inherited). Environment consists of configuration properties/values that are used to configure the system (see EnvironmentBuilder for more information). You can use system properties: 
         .environment()
    .systemProperties();
        Or, you can load properties from a file: 
         .environment()
    .properties("/path/to/file.properties")
        Or using directly a Properties object: 
         Properties myprops = new Properties();
 myprops.setProperty("foo", "bar");
 .environment()
    .properties(myprops)
        Or defining directly properties: 
         .environment()
    .properties()
       .set("foo", "bar")

        Every time you are configuring environment(), you update the same instance.

        Returns:
        the builder to configure properties handling

      • resource

        public StandaloneResourceResolutionBuilder<MessagingBuilder> resource()
        Cconfigures resource resolution.

        Resource resolution consists of finding a file:

        • either on filesystem
        • or in the classpath
        • or anywhere else

        To identify which resolution to use, each resolution is configured to handle one or several lookups prefixes. For example, if resolution is configured like this: 

         
 .string()
   .lookup("string:", "s:")
   .and()
 .file()
   .lookup("file:")
   .and()
 .classpath()
   .lookup("classpath:", "");
        Then you can reference a file that is in the classpath like this: 
         "classpath:foo/bar.html"

        Resource resolution is also able to handle path prefix and suffix. The aim is for example to have a folder that contains all templates. The developer then configures a path prefix for the folder. He can also configure a suffix to fix extension for templates. Thanks to those prefix/suffix, templates can now be referenced by the name of the file (without extension). It is useful to reference a template independently from where it is in reality (classpath, file or anywhere else) . Switching from classpath to file and conversely can be done easily (by updating the lookup). For example: 

         .classpath().lookup("classpath:").pathPrefix("foo/").pathSuffix(".html");
 
 resourceResolver.getResource("classpath:bar");
        The real path is then foo/bar.html.

        This implementation is used by MessagingBuilder for general configuration. That configuration may be inherited (applied to other resource resolution builders).

        Returns:
        the builder to configure resource resolution

      • mimetype

        public MimetypeDetectionBuilder<MessagingBuilder> mimetype()
        Builder that configures mimetype detection. There exists several implementations to provide the mimetype:
        • Using Java MimetypesFileTypeMap
        • Using Java 7 Files.probeContentType(java.nio.file.Path)
        • Using Apache Tika
        • Using JMimeMagic

        Both implementations provided by Java are based on file extensions. This can't be used in most cases as we often handle InputStreams.

        In previous version of Ogham, JMimeMagic was used and was working quite well. Unfortunately, the library is no more maintained.

        You can configure how Tika will detect mimetype: 

         .mimetype()
    .tika()
       ...

        This builder allows to use several providers. It will chain them until one can find a valid mimetype. If none is found, you can explicitly provide the default one: 

         .mimetype()
    .defaultMimetype("text/html")

        Every time you are configuring mimetype(), the same instance is used.

        Returns:
        the builder to configure mimetype detection

      • wrapUncaught

        public MessagingBuilder wrapUncaught(Boolean enable)
        There are technical exceptions that are thrown by libraries used by Ogham. Those exceptions are often RuntimeExceptions. It can be difficult for developers of a big application to quickly identify what caused this RuntimeException. The stack trace doesn't always help to find the real source of the error. If enables, this option ensures that work done by Ogham will always throw a MessagingException even if it was a RuntimeException thrown by any component. It then helps the developer to know that the error comes from Ogham or a any used library and not something else in its application. The other benefit is that in your code you only catch a MessagingException and you are sure that it will handle all cases, no surprise with an unchecked exception that could make a big failure in your system because you didn't know this could happen. Sending a message is often not critical (if message can't be sent now, it can be sent later or manually). It it fails the whole system must keep on working. With this option enabled, your system will never fail due to an unchecked exception and you can handle the failure the same way as with checked exceptions. Concretely, call of MessagingService.send(fr.sii.ogham.core.message.Message) catches all exceptions including RuntimeException. It wraps any exceptions into a MessagingException.

        The value set using this method takes precedence over any property and default value configured using wrapUncaught(). 

         .wrapUncaught(false)
 .wrapUncaught()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(true)
 
         .wrapUncaught(false)
 .wrapUncaught()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(true)
        In both cases, wrapUncaught(false) is used.

        If this method is called several times, only the last value is used.

        If null value is set, it is like not setting a value at all. The property/default value configuration is applied.

        Parameters:
        enable - enable or disable catching of unchecked exceptions
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • wrapUncaught

        public ConfigurationValueBuilder<MessagingBuilder,Boolean> wrapUncaught()
        There are technical exceptions that are thrown by libraries used by Ogham. Those exceptions are often RuntimeExceptions. It can be difficult for developers of a big application to quickly identify what caused this RuntimeException. The stack trace doesn't always help to find the real source of the error. If enables, this option ensures that work done by Ogham will always throw a MessagingException even if it was a RuntimeException thrown by any component. It then helps the developer to know that the error comes from Ogham or a any used library and not something else in its application. The other benefit is that in your code you only catch a MessagingException and you are sure that it will handle all cases, no surprise with an unchecked exception that could make a big failure in your system because you didn't know this could happen. Sending a message is often not critical (if message can't be sent now, it can be sent later or manually). It it fails the whole system must keep on working. With this option enabled, your system will never fail due to an unchecked exception and you can handle the failure the same way as with checked exceptions. Concretely, call of MessagingService.send(fr.sii.ogham.core.message.Message) catches all exceptions including RuntimeException. It wraps any exceptions into a MessagingException.

        This method is mainly used by Configurers to register some property keys and/or a default value. The aim is to let developer be able to externalize its configuration (using system properties, configuration file or anything else). If the developer doesn't configure any value for the registered properties, the default value is used (if set). 

         .wrapUncaught()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(true)

        Non-null value set using wrapUncaught(Boolean) takes precedence over property values and default value. 

         .wrapUncaught(false)
 .wrapUncaught()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(true)
        The value false is used regardless of the value of the properties and default value.

        See ConfigurationValueBuilder for more information.

        Returns:
        the builder to configure property keys/default value

      • email

        public EmailBuilder email()
        Configures how to send Email messages. It allows to:
        • register and configure several sender implementations
        • register and configure several template engines for parsing templates as message content
        • configure handling of missing Email information
        • configure handling of file attachments
        • configure CSS and image handling for Emails with an HTML body
        You can send an Email using the minimal behavior and using JavaMail implementation: 
         
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .email()
     .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)   // enable Email sending using JavaMail
       .host("your SMTP server host")
       .port("your SMTP server port")
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email
 service.send(new Email()
   .from("sender email address")
   .subject("email subject")
   .content("email body")
   .to("recipient email address"));
        You can also send an Email using a template (using Freemarker for example): The Freemarker template ("email/sample.html.ftl"): 
         <html>
 <head>
 </head>
 <body>
 Email content with variables: ${name} ${value}
 </body>
 </html>
        Then you can send the Email like this: 
         
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .email()
     .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)   // enable Email sending using JavaMail
       .host("your SMTP server host")
       .port("your SMTP server port")
       .and()
     .and()
   .template(FreemarkerEmailBuilder.class)  // enable templating using Freemarker
     .classpath()
       .lookup("classpath:")   // search resources/templates in the classpath if a path is prefixed by "classpath:"
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email
 service.send(new Email()
   .from("sender email address")
   .subject("email subject")
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:email/sample.html.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient email address"));

        Instead of explicitly configures SMTP host and port in your code, it could be better to externalize the configuration in a properties file for example (for example a file named "email.properties" in the classpath). The previous example becomes: 

         
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .environment()
     .properties("email.properties")
     .and()
   .email()
     .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)   // enable Email sending using JavaMail
       .host().properties("${mail.host}").and()
       .port().properties("${mail.port}").and()
       .and()
     .and()
   .template(FreemarkerEmailBuilder.class)  // enable templating using Freemarker
     .classpath()
       .lookup("classpath:")   // search resources/templates in the classpath if a path is prefixed by "classpath:"
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email
 service.send(new Email()
   .from("sender email address")
   .subject("email subject")
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:email/sample.html.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient email address"));
        The content of the file "email.properties": 
         mail.host=your STMP server host
 mail.port=your STMP server port
        Some fields of the Email may be automatically filled by a default value if they are not defined. For example, the sender address could be configured only once for your application: 
         
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .environment()
     .properties("email.properties")
     .and()
   .email()
     .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)   // enable Email sending using JavaMail
       .host().properties("${mail.host}").and()
       .port().properties("${mail.port}").and()
       .and()
     .autofill()    // enables and configures autofilling
       .from()
         .defaultValue().properties("${email.sender.address}").and()
         .and()
     .and()
   .template(FreemarkerEmailBuilder.class)  // enable templating using Freemarker
     .classpath()
       .lookup("classpath:")   // search resources/templates in the classpath if a path is prefixed by "classpath:"
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email (now the sender address can be omitted)
 service.send(new Email()
   .subject("email subject")
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:email/sample.html.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient email address"));
        The content of the file "email.properties": 
         mail.host=your STMP server host
 mail.port=your STMP server port
 email.sender.address=sender email address
        Another very useful automatic filling is for providing the email subject: 
         
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .environment()
     .properties("email.properties")
     .and()
   .email()
     .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)   // enable Email sending using JavaMail
       .host().properties("${mail.host}").and()
       .port().properties("${mail.port}").and()
       .and()
     .autofill()    // enables and configures autofilling
       .from()
         .defaultValue().properties("${email.sender.address}").and()
         .and()
       .subject()
         .htmlTitle(true)    // enables use of html title tag as subject
     .and()
   .template(FreemarkerEmailBuilder.class)  // enable templating using Freemarker
     .classpath()
       .lookup("classpath:")   // search resources/templates in the classpath if a path is prefixed by "classpath:"
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email (now the subject can be omitted)
 service.send(new Email()
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:email/sample.html.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient email address"));
        Change your template: 
         <html>
 <head>
   <title>email subject - ${name}</title>
 </head>
 <body>
 Email content with variables: ${name} ${value}
 </body>
 </html>
        The obvious advantage is that you have a single place to handle email content (body + subject). There is another benefit: you can also use variables in the subject. There many other configuration possibilities:
        • for configuring Emails with HTML content with a text fallback (useful for smartphones preview of your email for example)
        • for configuring attachments handling
        • for configuring image and css handling

        All the previous examples are provided to understand what can be configured. Hopefully, Ogham provides auto-configuration with a default behavior that fits 95% of usages. This auto-configuration is provided by MessagingConfigurers. Those configurers are automatically applied when using predefined MessagingBuilders like minimal() and standard(). The previous sample using standard configuration becomes: 

         
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .environment()
     .properties("email.properties")
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email
 service.send(new Email()
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:email/sample.html.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient email address"));
        The new content of the file "email.properties": 
         mail.host=your STMP server host
 mail.port=your STMP server port
 ogham.email.from.default-value=sender email address

        You can also use the auto-configuration for benefit from default behaviors and override some behaviors for your needs: 

         
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .environment()
     .properties("email.properties")
     .and()
   .email()
     .autofill()
       .from()
         .defaultValue().properties("${email.sender.address}").and()   // overrides default sender email address property
         .and()
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email
 service.send(new Email()
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:email/sample.html.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient email address"));
        The new content of the file "email.properties": 
         mail.host=your STMP server host
 mail.port=your STMP server port
 email.sender.address=sender email address
        Returns:
        the builder to configure how Email are handled

      • sms

        public SmsBuilder sms()
        Configures how to send Sms messages. It allows to:
        • register and configure several sender implementations
        • register and configure several template engines for parsing templates as message content
        • configure handling of missing Sms information
        • configure number format handling
        You can send a Sms using the minimal behavior and using Cloudhopper implementation: 
         
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .sms()
     .sender(CloudhopperBuilder.class)   // enable SMS sending using Cloudhopper
       .host("your SMPP server host")
       .port("your SMPP server port")
       .systemId("your SMPP system_id")
       .password("an optional password")
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the sms
 service.send(new Sms()
   .from("sender phone number")
   .content("sms content")
   .to("recipient phone number"));
        You can also send a Sms using a template (using Freemarker for example): The Freemarker template ("sms/sample.txt.ftl"): 
         Sms content with variables: ${name} ${value}
        Then you can send the Sms like this: 
         
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .sms()
     .sender(CloudhopperBuilder.class)   // enable SMS sending using Cloudhopper
       .host("your SMPP server host")
       .port("your SMPP server port")
       .systemId("your SMPP system_id")
       .password("an optional password")
       .and()
     .and()
   .template(FreemarkerSmsBuilder.class)  // enable templating using Freemarker
     .classpath()
       .lookup("classpath:")   // search resources/templates in the classpath if a path is prefixed by "classpath:"
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the sms
 service.send(new Sms()
   .from("sender phone number")
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:sms/sample.txt.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient phone number"));

        Instead of explicitly configures SMPP host/port/system_id/password in your code, it could be better to externalize the configuration in a properties file for example (for example a file named "sms.properties" in the classpath). The previous example becomes: 

         
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .environment()
     .properties("sms.properties")
     .and()
   .sms()
     .sender(CloudhopperBuilder.class)   // enable SMS sending using Cloudhopper
       .host().properties("${smpp.host}").and()
       .port().properties("${smpp.port}").and()
       .systemId().properties("${smpp.system-id}").and()
       .password().properties("${smpp.password}").and()
       .and()
     .and()
   .template(FreemarkerSmsBuilder.class)  // enable templating using Freemarker
     .classpath()
       .lookup("classpath:")   // search resources/templates in the classpath if a path is prefixed by "classpath:"
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the sms
 service.send(new Sms()
   .from("sender phone number")
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:sms/sample.txt.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient phone number"));
        The content of the file "sms.properties": 
         smpp.host=your SMPP server host
 smpp.port=your SMPP server port
 smpp.system-id=your SMPP system_id
 smpp.password=an optional password
        Some fields of the SMS may be automatically filled by a default value if they are not defined. For example, the sender phone number could be configured only once for your application: 
         
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .environment()
     .properties("sms.properties")
     .and()
   .sms()
     .sender(CloudhopperBuilder.class)   // enable SMS sending using Cloudhopper
       .host().properties("${smpp.host}").and()
       .port().properties("${smpp.port}").and()
       .systemId().properties("${smpp.system-id}").and()
       .password().properties("${smpp.password}").and()
       .and()
     .autofill()    // enables and configures autofilling
       .from()
         .defaultValue().properties("${sms.sender.number}").and()
         .and()
       .and()
     .and()
   .template(FreemarkerSmsBuilder.class)  // enable templating using Freemarker
     .classpath()
       .lookup("classpath:")   // search resources/templates in the classpath if a path is prefixed by "classpath:"
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the sms (now the sender phone number can be omitted)
 service.send(new Sms()
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:sms/sample.txt.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient phone number"));
        The new content of the file "sms.properties": 
         smpp.host=your SMPP server host
 smpp.port=your SMPP server port
 smpp.system-id=your SMPP system_id
 smpp.password=an optional password
 sms.sender.number=the sender phone number

        All the previous examples are provided to understand what can be configured. Hopefully, Ogham provides auto-configuration with a default behavior that fits 95% of usages. This auto-configuration is provided by MessagingConfigurers. Those configurers are automatically applied when using predefined MessagingBuilders like minimal() and standard(). The previous sample using standard configuration becomes: 

         
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standard()
   .environment()
     .properties("sms.properties")
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the sms
 service.send(new Sms()
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:sms/sample.txt.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient phone number"));
        The new content of the file "sms.properties": 
         ogham.sms.smpp.host=your SMPP server host
 ogham.sms.smpp.port=your SMPP server port
 ogham.sms.smpp.system-id=your SMPP system_id
 ogham.sms.smpp.password=an optional password
 ogham.sms.from.default-value=the sender phone number

        You can also use the auto-configuration for benefit from default behaviors and override some behaviors for your needs: 

         
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standard()
   .environment()
     .properties("sms.properties")
     .and()
   .sms()
     .autofill()
       .from()
         .defaultValue().properties("${sms.sender.number}").and()   // overrides default sender phone number property
         .and()
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the sms
 service.send(new Sms()
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:sms/sample.txt.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient phone number"));
        The new content of the file "sms.properties": 
         ogham.sms.smpp.host=your SMPP server host
 ogham.sms.smpp.port=your SMPP server port
 ogham.sms.smpp.system-id=your SMPP system_id
 ogham.sms.smpp.password=an optional password
 sms.sender.number=the sender phone number
        Returns:
        the builder to configure how SMS are handled

      • build

        public MessagingService build()
        Builds the messaging service. The messaging service relies on the generated senders. Each sender is able to manage one or multiple messages. The default implementation of the messaging service is to ask each sender if it is able to handle the message and if it the case, then use this sender to really send the message. This implementation doesn't stop when the message is handled by a sender to possibly let another send the message through another channel.

        If a RuntimeException is thrown while trying to send a message, the service will catch it and wrap it into a MessagingException in order to indicate that the exception was caused while trying to send a message.

        Specified by:
        build in interface Builder<MessagingService>
        Returns:
        the messaging service instance
        Throws:
        BuildException - when service couldn't be instantiated and configured

      • createResourceResolutionBuilder

        protected StandaloneResourceResolutionBuilder<MessagingBuilder> createResourceResolutionBuilder()

      • createMimetypeBuilder

        protected MimetypeDetectionBuilder<MessagingBuilder> createMimetypeBuilder()

      • createCleanable

        protected Cleanable createCleanable()

      • createRegistry

        protected Registry<Object> createRegistry()

      • getOrCreateCleanableRegistry

        protected CleanableRegistry getOrCreateCleanableRegistry()

      • createEnvironmentBuilder

        protected EnvironmentBuilder<MessagingBuilder> createEnvironmentBuilder()

      • createBuildContext

        protected BuildContext createBuildContext()

      • empty

        public static MessagingBuilder empty()
        Static factory method that initializes a MessagingBuilder instance with no auto-configuration at all.
        Returns:
        the empty builder that provides no behavior at all that needs to be configured

      • standard

        public static MessagingBuilder standard()
        Static factory method that initializes a MessagingBuilder instance and auto-configures it with a predefined behavior named "standard". Usage example: 
         
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standard()
   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .build();

        Basically, the standard behavior:

        • Enables all template engines that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Enables all Email sender implementations that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Enables all Sms sender implementations that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Catches all uncaught exception to wrap them in order to avoid unwanted unchecked exception
        • Uses system properties
        • Enables and configures useful auto-filling mechanisms (using property values and providing email subject from templates)
        • Enables mimetype detection
        • Enables locating templates, css, images and all other resources using lookup prefix ("file:" for files that are present on the filesystem, "classpath:" and "" for files that are present in the classpath)
        • Enables use of some properties to provide path prefix/suffix for locating resources
        • Enables images and css inlining used by HTML Emails

        The auto-configurers ( MessagingConfigurers) are automatically loaded from the classpath. Only configurers that are in "fr.sii.ogham" package and sub-packages are loaded. If you want to load from other packages, use standard(String...). Some Ogham modules are optional meaning that according to used modules, the behavior will vary. Loaded MessagingConfigurers are applied to the MessagingBuilder only if they are for the "standard" builder. It is accomplished thanks to the ConfigurerFor annotation (only configurers annotated and with ConfigurerFor.targetedBuilder() set to "standard"). Loaded configurers with priorities are (if all Ogham modules are used):

        • DefaultMessagingConfigurer: 100000
        • DefaultThymeleafEmailConfigurer: 90000
        • DefaultFreemarkerEmailConfigurer: 80000
        • DefaultThymeleafSmsConfigurer: 70000
        • DefaultFreemarkerSmsConfigurer: 60000
        • DefaultJavaMailConfigurer: 50000
        • DefaultCloudhopperConfigurer: 40000
        • DefaultSendGridConfigurer: 30000
        • DefaultOvhSmsConfigurer: 20000
        TODO: link to whole configuration that is applied by standard

        The auto-configured MessagingBuilder will provide a default behavior that fits 95% of usages. You can still override some behaviors for your needs. For example: 

         
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standard()
   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .wrapUncaught(false)    // overrides and disables wrapUncaught option
   .build();
        Returns:
        the messaging builder that can be customized

      • standard

        public static MessagingBuilder standard(String... basePackages)
        Static factory method that initializes a MessagingBuilder instance and auto-configures it with a predefined behavior named "standard". Usage example:

   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .build();

        • Uses system properties
        • Enables and configures useful auto-filling mechanisms (using property values and providing email subject from templates)
        • Enables mimetype detection
        • Enables locating templates, css, images and all other resources using lookup prefix ("file:" for files that are present on the filesystem, "classpath:" and "" for files that are present in the classpath)
        • Enables use of some properties to provide path prefix/suffix for locating resources
        • Enables images and css inlining used by HTML Emails

        The auto-configurers ( MessagingConfigurers) are automatically loaded from the classpath. Only configurers that are in the provided packages and sub-packages are loaded. Some Ogham modules are optional meaning that according to used modules, the behavior will vary. Loaded MessagingConfigurers are applied to the MessagingBuilder only if they are for the "standard" builder.    .environment()

     .and()

   .build();
        Parameters:
        basePackages - the base packages that are scanned to find MessagingConfigurer implementations
        Returns:
        the messaging builder that can be customized

      • standard

        public static MessagingBuilder standard(boolean autoconfigure)
        Static factory method that initializes a MessagingBuilder instance and registers auto-configures but doesn't apply them if autoconfigure parameter is false. The configure(ConfigurationPhase) method must be called manually. Usage example: 
         
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standard()
   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .build();

        Basically, the standard behavior:

        • Enables all template engines that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Enables all Email sender implementations that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Enables all Sms sender implementations that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Catches all uncaught exception to wrap them in order to avoid unwanted unchecked exception
        • Uses system properties
        • Enables and configures useful auto-filling mechanisms (using property values and providing email subject from templates)
        • Enables mimetype detection
        • Enables locating templates, css, images and all other resources using lookup prefix ("file:" for files that are present on the filesystem, "classpath:" and "" for files that are present in the classpath)
        • Enables use of some properties to provide path prefix/suffix for locating resources
        • Enables images and css inlining used by HTML Emails

        The auto-configurers ( MessagingConfigurers) are automatically loaded from the classpath. Only configurers that are in "fr.sii.ogham" package and sub-packages are loaded. If you want to load from other packages, use standard(String...). Some Ogham modules are optional meaning that according to used modules, the behavior will vary. Loaded MessagingConfigurers are applied to the MessagingBuilder only if they are for the "standard" builder. It is accomplished thanks to the ConfigurerFor annotation (only configurers annotated and with ConfigurerFor.targetedBuilder() set to "standard"). Loaded configurers with priorities are (if all Ogham modules are used):

        • DefaultMessagingConfigurer: 100000
        • DefaultThymeleafEmailConfigurer: 90000
        • DefaultFreemarkerEmailConfigurer: 80000
        • DefaultThymeleafSmsConfigurer: 70000
        • DefaultFreemarkerSmsConfigurer: 60000
        • DefaultJavaMailConfigurer: 50000
        • DefaultCloudhopperConfigurer: 40000
        • DefaultSendGridConfigurer: 30000
        • DefaultOvhSmsConfigurer: 20000
        TODO: link to whole configuration that is applied by standard

        The auto-configured MessagingBuilder will provide a default behavior that fits 95% of usages. You can still override some behaviors for your needs. For example: 

         
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standard()
   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .wrapUncaught(false)    // overrides and disables wrapUncaught option
   .build();
        Parameters:
        autoconfigure - true to automatically apply found configurers, false to configure manually later by calling configure(ConfigurationPhase)
        Returns:
        the messaging builder that can be customized

      • standard

        public static MessagingBuilder standard(boolean autoconfigure,
                                        String... basePackages)
        Static factory method that initializes a MessagingBuilder instance and registers auto-configures but doesn't apply them if autoconfigure parameter is false. The configure(ConfigurationPhase) method must be called manually. Usage example: 
         
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standard()
   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .build();

        Basically, the standard behavior:

        • Enables all template engines that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Enables all Email sender implementations that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Enables all Sms sender implementations that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Catches all uncaught exception to wrap them in order to avoid unwanted unchecked exception
        • Uses system properties
        • Enables and configures useful auto-filling mechanisms (using property values and providing email subject from templates)
        • Enables mimetype detection
        • Enables locating templates, css, images and all other resources using lookup prefix ("file:" for files that are present on the filesystem, "classpath:" and "" for files that are present in the classpath)
        • Enables use of some properties to provide path prefix/suffix for locating resources
        • Enables images and css inlining used by HTML Emails

        The auto-configurers ( MessagingConfigurers) are automatically loaded from the classpath. Only configurers that are in the provided packages and sub-packages are loaded. Some Ogham modules are optional meaning that according to used modules, the behavior will vary. Loaded MessagingConfigurers are applied to the MessagingBuilder only if they are for the "standard" builder. It is accomplished thanks to the ConfigurerFor annotation (only configurers annotated and with ConfigurerFor.targetedBuilder() set to "standard"). Loaded configurers with priorities are (if all Ogham modules are used):

        • DefaultMessagingConfigurer: 100000
        • DefaultThymeleafEmailConfigurer: 90000
        • DefaultFreemarkerEmailConfigurer: 80000

        • DefaultFreemarkerSmsConfigurer: 60000

   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()

      • standard

        public static <T extends MessagingBuilder> T standard(Supplier<T> factory,
                                                      boolean autoconfigure,
                                                      String... basePackages)
        Static factory method that initializes a MessagingBuilder instance and registers auto-configures but doesn't apply them if autoconfigure parameter is false. The configure(ConfigurationPhase) method must be called manually.

        This method allows to use a custom MessagingBuilder implementation.

        NOTE: This is for advanced usage only. Usage example: 

         
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standard()
   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .build();

        Basically, the standard behavior:

        • Enables all template engines that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Enables all Email sender implementations that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Enables all Sms sender implementations that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Catches all uncaught exception to wrap them in order to avoid unwanted unchecked exception
        • Uses system properties
        • Enables and configures useful auto-filling mechanisms (using property values and providing email subject from templates)
        • Enables mimetype detection
        • Enables locating templates, css, images and all other resources using lookup prefix ("file:" for files that are present on the filesystem, "classpath:" and "" for files that are present in the classpath)
        • Enables use of some properties to provide path prefix/suffix for locating resources
        • Enables images and css inlining used by HTML Emails

        The auto-configurers ( MessagingConfigurers) are automatically loaded from the classpath. Only configurers that are in the provided packages and sub-packages are loaded. Some Ogham modules are optional meaning that according to used modules, the behavior will vary. Loaded MessagingConfigurers are applied to the MessagingBuilder only if they are for the "standard" builder. It is accomplished thanks to the ConfigurerFor annotation (only configurers annotated and with ConfigurerFor.targetedBuilder() set to "standard"). Loaded configurers with priorities are (if all Ogham modules are used):

        • DefaultMessagingConfigurer: 100000
        • DefaultThymeleafEmailConfigurer: 90000
        • DefaultFreemarkerEmailConfigurer: 80000
        • DefaultThymeleafSmsConfigurer: 70000
        • DefaultFreemarkerSmsConfigurer: 60000
        • DefaultJavaMailConfigurer: 50000
        • DefaultCloudhopperConfigurer: 40000
        • DefaultSendGridConfigurer: 30000
        • DefaultOvhSmsConfigurer: 20000
        TODO: link to whole configuration that is applied by standard

        The auto-configured MessagingBuilder will provide a default behavior that fits 95% of usages. You can still override some behaviors for your needs. For example: 

         
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standard()
   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .wrapUncaught(false)    // overrides and disables wrapUncaught option
   .build();
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of final MessagingBuilder
        Parameters:
        factory - the factory used to create the MessagingBuilder instance
        autoconfigure - true to automatically apply found configurers, false to configure manually later by calling configure(ConfigurationPhase)
        basePackages - the base packages that are scanned to find MessagingConfigurer implementations
        Returns:
        the messaging builder that can be customized

      • minimal

        public static MessagingBuilder minimal()
        Static factory method that initializes a MessagingBuilder instance and auto-configures it with a predefined behavior named "minimal". Usage example: 
         
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.minimal()
   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .build();

        Basically, the minimal behavior:

        • Enables all template engines that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Catches all uncaught exception to wrap them in order to avoid unwanted unchecked exception
        • Uses system properties
        • Enables and configures useful auto-filling mechanisms (using property values and providing email subject from templates)
        • Enables mimetype detection
        • Enables locating templates, css, images and all other resources using lookup prefix ("file:" for files that are present on the filesystem, "classpath:" and "" for files that are present in the classpath)
        • Enables use of some properties to provide path prefix/suffix for locating resources
        • Enables images and css inlining used by HTML Emails
        The minimal behavior doesn't automatically auto-configure sender implementations.

        The auto-configurers ( MessagingConfigurers) are automatically loaded from the classpath. Only configurers that are in "fr.sii.ogham" package and sub-packages are loaded. If you want to load from other packages, use minimal(String...). Some Ogham modules are optional meaning that according to used modules, the behavior will vary. Loaded MessagingConfigurers are applied to the MessagingBuilder only if they are for the "minimal" builder. It is accomplished thanks to the ConfigurerFor annotation (only configurers annotated and with ConfigurerFor.targetedBuilder() set to "minimal"). Loaded configurers with priorities are (if all Ogham modules are used):

        • DefaultMessagingConfigurer: 100000
        • DefaultThymeleafEmailConfigurer: 90000
        • DefaultFreemarkerEmailConfigurer: 80000
        • DefaultThymeleafSmsConfigurer: 70000
        • DefaultFreemarkerSmsConfigurer: 60000
        TODO: link to whole configuration that is applied by minimal

        The auto-configured MessagingBuilder will provide a default behavior with no sender implementation. This is useful if you only want to use a particular implementation or your custom sender implementation. You can still override some behaviors for your needs. For example: 

         
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.minimal()
   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .wrapUncaught(false)    // overrides and disables wrapUncaught option
   .build();
        Returns:
        the messaging builder that can be customized

      • minimal

        public static MessagingBuilder minimal(String... basePackages)
        Static factory method that initializes a MessagingBuilder instance and auto-configures it with a predefined behavior named "minimal". Usage example:

   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .build();

        • Enables mimetype detection
        • Enables locating templates, css, images and all other resources using lookup prefix ("file:" for files that are present on the filesystem, "classpath:" and "" for files that are present in the classpath)
        • Enables use of some properties to provide path prefix/suffix for locating resources
        • Enables images and css inlining used by HTML Emails
        The minimal behavior doesn't automatically auto-configure sender implementations.

        The auto-configurers ( MessagingConfigurers) are automatically loaded from the classpath. Only configurers that are in the provided packages and sub-packages are loaded.         • DefaultMessagingConfigurer: 100000
        • DefaultThymeleafEmailConfigurer: 90000
        • DefaultFreemarkerEmailConfigurer: 80000
        • DefaultThymeleafSmsConfigurer: 70000
        • DefaultFreemarkerSmsConfigurer: 60000
        TODO: link to whole configuration that is applied by minimal

        The auto-configured MessagingBuilder will provide a default behavior with no sender implementation. This is useful if you only want to use a particular implementation or your custom sender implementation. You can still override some behaviors for your needs. For example: 

         
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.minimal()
   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .wrapUncaught(false)    // overrides and disables wrapUncaught option
   .build();
        Parameters:
        basePackages - the base packages that are scanned to find MessagingConfigurer implementations
        Returns:
        the messaging builder that can be customized

      • minimal

        public static MessagingBuilder minimal(boolean autoconfigure)
        Static factory method that initializes a MessagingBuilder instance and registers auto-configures but doesn't apply them if autoconfigure parameter is false. The configure(ConfigurationPhase) method must be called manually. Usage example: 
         
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.minimal()
   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .build();

        Basically, the minimal behavior:

        • Enables all template engines that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Catches all uncaught exception to wrap them in order to avoid unwanted unchecked exception
        • Uses system properties
        • Enables and configures useful auto-filling mechanisms (using property values and providing email subject from templates)
        • Enables mimetype detection
        • Enables locating templates, css, images and all other resources using lookup prefix ("file:" for files that are present on the filesystem, "classpath:" and "" for files that are present in the classpath)
        • Enables use of some properties to provide path prefix/suffix for locating resources
        • Enables images and css inlining used by HTML Emails
        The minimal behavior doesn't automatically auto-configure sender implementations.

        The auto-configurers ( MessagingConfigurers) are automatically loaded from the classpath. Only configurers that are in "fr.sii.ogham" package and sub-packages are loaded. If you want to load from other packages, use minimal(String...). Some Ogham modules are optional meaning that according to used modules, the behavior will vary. Loaded MessagingConfigurers are applied to the MessagingBuilder only if they are for the "minimal" builder. It is accomplished thanks to the ConfigurerFor annotation (only configurers annotated and with ConfigurerFor.targetedBuilder() set to "minimal"). Loaded configurers with priorities are (if all Ogham modules are used):

        • DefaultMessagingConfigurer: 100000
        • DefaultThymeleafEmailConfigurer: 90000
        • DefaultFreemarkerEmailConfigurer: 80000
        • DefaultThymeleafSmsConfigurer: 70000
        • DefaultFreemarkerSmsConfigurer: 60000
        TODO: link to whole configuration that is applied by minimal

        The auto-configured MessagingBuilder will provide a default behavior with no sender implementation. This is useful if you only want to use a particular implementation or your custom sender implementation. You can still override some behaviors for your needs. For example: 

         
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.minimal()
   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .wrapUncaught(false)    // overrides and disables wrapUncaught option
   .build();
        Parameters:
        autoconfigure - true to automatically apply found configurers, false to configure manually later by calling configure(ConfigurationPhase)
        Returns:
        the messaging builder that can be customized

      • minimal

        public static MessagingBuilder minimal(boolean autoconfigure,
                                       String... basePackages)
        Static factory method that initializes a MessagingBuilder instance and registers auto-configures but doesn't apply them if autoconfigure parameter is false. The configure(ConfigurationPhase) method must be called manually. Usage example:

   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .build();

        Basically, the minimal behavior:

        • Catches all uncaught exception to wrap them in order to avoid unwanted unchecked exception

        • Enables and configures useful auto-filling mechanisms (using property values and providing email subject from templates)

        • Enables locating templates, css, images and all other resources using lookup prefix ("file:" for files that are present on the filesystem, "classpath:" and "" for files that are present in the classpath)
        • Enables use of some properties to provide path prefix/suffix for locating resources
        • Enables images and css inlining used by HTML Emails
        The minimal behavior doesn't automatically auto-configure sender implementations.

        The auto-configurers ( MessagingConfigurers) are automatically loaded from the classpath. Only configurers that are in the provided packages and sub-packages are loaded. Some Ogham modules are optional meaning that according to used modules, the behavior will vary. Loaded MessagingConfigurers are applied to the MessagingBuilder only if they are for the "minimal" builder. It is accomplished thanks to the ConfigurerFor annotation (only configurers annotated and with ConfigurerFor.targetedBuilder() set to "minimal").       • minimal

        public static <T extends MessagingBuilder> T minimal(Supplier<T> factory,
                                                     boolean autoconfigure,
                                                     String... basePackages)
        Static factory method that initializes a MessagingBuilder instance and registers auto-configures but doesn't apply them if autoconfigure parameter is false. The configure(ConfigurationPhase) method must be called manually.

        This method allows to use a custom MessagingBuilder implementation.

        NOTE: This is for advanced usage only. Usage example: 

         
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.minimal()
   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .build();

        Basically, the minimal behavior:

        • Enables all template engines that are present in the classpath and configures them
        • Catches all uncaught exception to wrap them in order to avoid unwanted unchecked exception
        • Uses system properties
        • Enables and configures useful auto-filling mechanisms (using property values and providing email subject from templates)
        • Enables mimetype detection
        • Enables locating templates, css, images and all other resources using lookup prefix ("file:" for files that are present on the filesystem, "classpath:" and "" for files that are present in the classpath)
        • Enables use of some properties to provide path prefix/suffix for locating resources
        • Enables images and css inlining used by HTML Emails
        The minimal behavior doesn't automatically auto-configure sender implementations.

        The auto-configurers ( MessagingConfigurers) are automatically loaded from the classpath. Only configurers that are in the provided packages and sub-packages are loaded. Some Ogham modules are optional meaning that according to used modules, the behavior will vary. Loaded MessagingConfigurers are applied to the MessagingBuilder only if they are for the "minimal" builder. It is accomplished thanks to the ConfigurerFor annotation (only configurers annotated and with ConfigurerFor.targetedBuilder() set to "minimal"). Loaded configurers with priorities are (if all Ogham modules are used):

        • DefaultMessagingConfigurer: 100000
        • DefaultThymeleafEmailConfigurer: 90000
        • DefaultFreemarkerEmailConfigurer: 80000
        • DefaultThymeleafSmsConfigurer: 70000
        • DefaultFreemarkerSmsConfigurer: 60000
        TODO: link to whole configuration that is applied by minimal

        The auto-configured MessagingBuilder will provide a default behavior with no sender implementation. This is useful if you only want to use a particular implementation or your custom sender implementation. You can still override some behaviors for your needs. For example: 

         
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.minimal()
   .environment()
     .properties("application.properties")
     .and()
   .wrapUncaught(false)    // overrides and disables wrapUncaught option
   .build();
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of final MessagingBuilder
        Parameters:
        factory - the factory used to create the MessagingBuilder instance
        autoconfigure - true to automatically apply found configurers, false to configure manually later by calling configure(ConfigurationPhase)
        basePackages - the base packages that are scanned to find MessagingConfigurer implementations
        Returns:
        the messaging builder that can be customized

      • findAndRegister

        public static void findAndRegister(MessagingBuilder builder,
                                   String builderName,
                                   String... basePackages)
        You can use this method if standard() and minimal() factory methods doesn't fit your needs. The aim is to auto-configure a builder with matching configurers. Utility method that searches all MessagingConfigurers that are in the classpath. Only configurers that are in the provided packages (and sub-packages) are loaded. Once configurers are found, they are filtered thanks to information provided by ConfigurerFor annotation. Only configurers with ConfigurerFor.targetedBuilder() value that matches the builderName parameter are kept. The found and filtered configurers are registered into the provided builder instance.
        Parameters:
        builder - the builder to configure with matching configurers
        builderName - the name that is referenced by ConfigurerFor.targetedBuilder()
        basePackages - the packages that are scanned to find MessagingConfigurer implementations
